Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: F: Study of a Cyber-Enabled Social Computing Framework for Improving Practice in Online Computing Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data science techniques have revolutionized many academic fields and led to terrific gains in the commercial sector. They have to date been underutilized in solving critical problems in the US educational system, particularly in understanding Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and increasing retention for students traditionally underserved in STEM. The goals of the Directorate for Education and Human Resources through the Critical Techniques and Technologies for Advancing Foundations and Applications of Big Data Science & Engineering (BIGDATA) program are to advance fundamental understanding of key questions in the field, and catalyze the use of data science in Education Research. Computing has become an integral part of the practice of in modern science, technology engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. As a result, the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to integrate the use of computational approaches in STEM teaching and learning and understand how this integration can improve STEM learning, engagement, and persistence. In this proposal, the Principal Investigators (PIs) will examine environments that many people engage in independently to learn computing, online communities and massive open online courses (MOOCs). This activity could be very compelling as people come to these environments because they have personal goals to learn the material. However, a challenge in these environments is that there is little support for learning. In addition, these environments are not adaptive to learners' needs. This project will tackle both of these challenges. The PIs will first characterize groups of learners to understand their needs and then design approaches to personalizing the environments based on those needs.

The PIs address a need for both learning and independent online work communities by providing a combined learning work community. Many authentic production communitites, such as GitHub, do not provide support for novices who want to learn to contribute. Similarly many learning communities, such as MOOCs and other online learning environments, do not provide outlets for learners' products to become authentic. The PIs will combine data from MOOCs and online communities to discover groups of participants who behave in similar ways and investigate how to support the needs of these groups. This will lead to the proposed novel combined learning and work community that both provides support and offers authentic outlets for work products that are valued beyond a particular course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BIG DATA: Collaborative Research Project focused on learning design models and approaches for teaching and learning at scale. Scale often involves tens of thousands of learners. The existing learning design literature has focused on smaller scale learning relationships where an educator plans and enacts instructional and learning opportunities in a 1:25 or 1:100+ ratio. The growth of digital learning now allows much larger student populations. Massive open online courses (MOOCs) often include thousands of students. When students scale, but teachers remain constant, new pedagogical models are required. These models include greater peer-to-peer interactions, greater support of AI or automated support, increased engagement with course materials, and emphasis on self-regulation of individual learners. This project was concerned with community formation in these types of large scale learning environments. UTA's contribution involved exploring the learning design and automated support to make that community creation possible.

Specific project outcomes:

1. The development of numerous open online courses (seven courses in total with combined registration of over 50,000 students) on edX in two distinct areas, 1. a certificate in Learning Analytics and 2. a wellbeing and personal wellness course (Yoga). These two topics were selected because they were expected to appeal to different learner profiles as well as different content (technical and non-technical subject areas).

2. The application of S-I-R framework, from epidemiology, to model how ideas spread when learners engage in social interaction. By modeling how learner interactions influence the spread of ideas, learning design models can be developed that promote effective peer-to-peer idea development

3. The utilization of automated feedback (through the open source tool OnTask (www.ontasklearning.org) in large scale learning analytics courses offered on edX. Automated feedback, when combined with SIR models of interaction, can help in promoting deeper levels of engagement and learning in student cohorts and communities.

4. The development of a learning design model that enacts group learning, social capital, and peer-based teaching in large scale digital learning. This model underpins the MOOCs developed as part of this project and continues to inform innovative course development with UTA's edX partnership.

These outcomes are consistent with the proposal's stated intellectual merit "The design principles, interaction paradigms, and algorithms developed in this work will lead to more effective online communities, fueling more efficient and effective learning and work".

The broader impact of UTA's work (network models of idea development, learning design model for peer-based learning, adaptive feedback) meets the intended project outcome of supporting "group processes in online communities for future research in the broader area of social computing that will achieve a greater level of awareness of individual differences". Individualization, even in large scale courses, requires new models and new technologies. This project provides important advancements for both researchers and practitioners in how to design, deploy, and assess learner performance at scale.
